articles.title: Outdoor skating areas in Lethbridge close as temperatures climb
articles.author: CTV
articles.summary: Mother Nature's recent shift in temperature is to blame for the recent temperature change. It's been warmer recently. It may continue to be so for the next few days. It will get colder in the coming days.   Â. Â

articles.title: Collab with all stakeholders to combat climate change
articles.author: Juiceapac Web Development Team
articles.summary: The State Government will collaborate with all stakeholders to combat climate change and its challenges, said Chief Minister Datuk Seri Hajiji Noor. He was speaking at the Kinabalu Convention 2025: Food Security, Climate Change and Investment at the Magellan Sutera Resort, here, Monday.

articles.title: Outdoor skating areas in Lethbridge close as temperatures climb
articles.author: CTVNews Calgary.ca Staff
articles.summary: All outdoor skating areas in Lethbridge, Alta., have been closed effective immediately due to the recent shift in the temperature.   Â     .   in the Lethbridge area is closed due to Mother Nature's shift in temperature.

articles.title: Iowa weather: This week's warm-up among the biggest in February history
articles.author: Zane Satre
articles.summary: Temperatures rose 68 degrees in Des Moines from last Tuesday morning to this Monday afternoon. That's one of the biggest warm-ups in a seven-day period since February records began. The biggest one-week warm-up was 85 degrees in February 1981.

articles.title: See photos of progress TVA, TEMA are making to remove Helene debris from Douglas Lake
articles.author: Brianna Paciorka
articles.summary: Debris from Hurricane Helene is removed from the shoreline of Douglas Lake in Dandridge on Monday, February 24, 2025. Equipment used to remove the debris from the lake is seen at right on Douglas Lake. Debris from Helene debris is burned along the lake.

articles.title: Virgin pilot alerted authorities to Chinese live fire drills off Australian coast
articles.author: Joseph Olbrycht-Palmer
articles.summary: Virgin Australia pilot alerted authorities about Chinese live fire drills off Australia's east coast last week. The exercises forced at least two commercial flights to change course. A trio of Chinese warships were conducting the drills in the Tasman Sea, between Australia and New Zealand. The Albanese government has formally protested the drills.

articles.title: Virgin Australia pilot alerted authorities to Chinese live fire drills off Australian coast
articles.author: Joseph Olbrycht-Palmer
articles.summary: Virgin Australia pilot alerted authorities about Chinese live fire drills off Australia's east coast last week. The exercises forced dozens of flights to change course. Chinese warships were conducting drills on Friday and Saturday in international waters between Australia and New Zealand. The Albanese government has formally protested them. China has accused Australia of making 'hyped' claims.

articles.title: Bird deaths in Pflugerville caused by cold temperatures, TPWD says
articles.author: Anthony Torres
articles.summary: There were bird deaths at Lake Pflugerville over the weekend due to cold temperatures. Purple Martins are insectivores and probably didn't get enough bugs to keep up their metabolic rates in the cold. The situation will be reassessed if temperatures warm up.

articles.title: Scientists Find Greenland Ice Sheet's Point of No Return
articles.author: Arden Dier
articles.summary: Greenland's ice sheet is losing a lot of ice every hour. It's one of only two permanent ice sheets on Earth. Global warming could cause the collapse of the Greenland ice sheet within 75 years. It could also cause 23 feet of sea level rise.

articles.title: Calling for a magic wand: Dutton's nuclear policy to add 2 billion tonnes of CO2
articles.author: Bernard Keane
articles.summary: Coalition's nuclear policy would add at least two billion tonnes to Australia's CO2-equivalent emissions over twenty-five years. It would be well short of Australia's legislated 43% emissions reduction target for 2030, not meeting it until late in the 2030s. Under the alternative pathway, national emissions would still be 40% below the 2005 baseline by 2035.

articles.title: Wrong, The Guardian, There Are No Identifiable 'Climate Tipping Points'
articles.author: Guest Blogger
articles.summary: There is no evidence that we are approaching dangerous and unprecedented climate tipping points. The planet has been through periods of massive change many times in the past. The main theme for all of Earth's history has been climate change. The most common threshold value for global average temperature is 1.5°C above pre-industrial temperatures. Europe has long surpassed that value, with a temperature record going back to the 1700s.

articles.title: 'Reforming the National Climate Assessment: A Call for Sanity Over Alarmism', by Charles Rotter
articles.author: Daniel Meegan
articles.summary: The U.S. National Climate Assessment (NCA) is a one-sided document that reflects the priorities of whoever's in power. Patrick Brown, a climate scientist at the Breakthrough Institute, proposes five changes to the NCA to make it a tool for understanding rather than a cudgel for political mobilization.

articles.title: Millions to sweat through final summer burst of heat
articles.author: Adam Vidler
articles.summary: Summer will give way to autumn on Saturday. The Bureau of Meteorology has forecast a top of 32 degrees for Sydney on Friday. Melbourne is set to reach 34 degrees tomorrow. Adelaide is predicted to reach 33 degrees today, followed by tops of 31 for Wednesday and Thursday. Brisbane's temperatures are forecast to hover around 31 or 30 degrees all week.

articles.title: Millions to sweat through final summer burst of heat
articles.author: Adam Vidler8:15am
articles.summary: It's the final week of summer in Australia. High-pressure system over Great Australian Bight is bringing hot, dry air south. Sydney will reach 32 degrees on Friday. Melbourne will reach 34 degrees tomorrow. Adelaide will reach 33 degrees today, followed by tops of 31 for Wednesday and Thursday. Darwin will see 33 and 34 degrees for the rest of the week, before getting hotter next week.

articles.title: This Republican Is Spreading the Word About Climate Change, One Garden Club at a Time
articles.author: Tess Bonn
articles.summary: Kathleen Biggins started C-Change Conversations, a nonprofit aimed at helping people understand the science of climate change. She has made presentations to more than 21,000 people across 33 states, including in her own hometown of Princeton, New Jersey. According to a Pew Research Center study, 51% of U.S. adults felt suspicious of groups advocating for climate action, including 75% of Republicans.

articles.title: Special weather statement issued due to high winds
articles.author: CTV
articles.summary: The melt is on across southern Ontario, but the wind has picked up as well, so the wind is picking up too, which is bad for the snowfall.   Â. Â   y   in southern Ontario.  Y

articles.title: The Great Climate Grift
articles.author: Dr. Matthew Wielicki
articles.summary: Politico's article about Trump's climate policy is an example of how mainstream media constructs narratives out of thin air. Global greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions have continued to rise, climate spending has ballooned into the trillions, and there is no measurable impact to show for it.

articles.title: Mega-iceberg from Antarctica is headed toward South Georgia—here's what could happen
articles.author: Science X staff
articles.summary: There is a lot of research going on in this project. It's not clear what is going to happen next, but it's going to be a lot more complicated. The research is going on at a number of different places. It is not clear if the project will be successful.

articles.title: Coast Guard urges caution as fluctuating temps threaten ice safety on the Great Lakes
articles.author: Michelle Wenz
articles.summary: The Coast Guard reminds the public to use caution when entering areas around icy waters as temperatures fluctuate across the Great Lakes region. The thickness of the ice can vary around bridges, narrow spots, inlets and outlets, pressure ridges, slushy areas, and cracks.

articles.title: Farmers, investors, miners and parents: how unconventional climate advocates can reach new audiences
articles.author: Kelly Fielding
articles.summary: Unconventional climate advocates are those not from the stereotypical background and who belong to holdout groups. They can play a crucial role in expanding the base of the climate movement without working with mainstream climate groups. Unconventional advocates received less media coverage than other types of advocates but received more sympathetic coverage.

articles.title: Seaqaqa residents affected as several key crossings remain under water
articles.author: fijivillage
articles.summary: Floodwaters continue to block key crossings in Seaqaqaqa, with Colo Bridge, Lalakoro Crossing and Batiri Jalav Road still under water. Heavy rain yesterday led to flooding at Colo Bridge. Vegetable crops and sugarcane fields have been affected by the flooding.

articles.title: When Is the Best Time to Visit Australia?
articles.author: Anthony Battalio
articles.summary: In New Jersey, seasons are defined by snowstorms and hot summers. In Australia, there are four seasons, ranging from cool winters (June-August) to comfortably warm summers (December-February). The peak tourist season in Australia is from December to February, when beaches buzz with sun-seekers and city streets filled with energy. The peak off-peak season is from May to August, when the pace slows down.

articles.title: Australia unlikely to break its weather cycle as data points to 'significant chance' 2025 will be nation's sixth wetter than average year in a row
articles.author: Rob Sharpe
articles.summary: Australia's last five years have all been wetter than usual. The last time Australia had such consistent wet weather was a seven-year stretch from 1995 to 2001. The Pacific Ocean is in a 'La Nina-like' state but hasn't consistently met the thresholds to be an official La Nina event. El Nino has a 20% chance of developing in the springtime.

articles.title: What does USAID do for the climate, and how will that change if it's gone?
articles.author: Roddy Scheer
articles.summary: President Trump wants to dismantle the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID). USAID has been a leader in global environmental efforts, supporting initiatives that promote sustainability, cut emissions and build resilience in vulnerable regions. USAID's Climate Strategy (2022-2030) outlines a plan for reducing emissions, enhancing resilience and promoting sustainable development across multiple sectors and regions.

articles.title: Karamoja's economic potential unfulfilled due to ongoing conflicts and climate change
articles.summary: Karamoja remains one of Uganda's richest regions, but its economic potential remains unfulfilled due to ongoing conflicts and climate change, according to a newly released climate and conflict situation report. The conflicts are mostly involving small arms, aggravated by the impact of climate change.

articles.title: Mountain snowpack continues to run well above average in Northeastern Oregon
articles.author: Baker City Herald
articles.summary: The mountain snowpack in Northeastern Oregon is well above average in most areas and setting all-time records for late February at a few sites. The first half of February brought a series of snowstorms and an arctic outbreak during which temperatures plunged well below zero across much of the region.

articles.title: Weather to Start Improving on Wednesday, Says EMA
articles.author: Rana Atef
articles.summary: The General Authority for Meteorology has announced the expected end date of the severe cold wave affecting the country. Tuesday will be the last day of the cold wave. Starting Wednesday, February 26, a slight and gradual increase in temperatures is expected across most areas. There is a chance of light to moderate rain on the northeastern coasts and light rain over northern Lower Egypt, accompanied by active winds.

articles.title: Kasese district faces devastating impact of climate change
articles.summary: Kasese district is one of the most affected areas in Uganda by climate change. The region has experienced an alarming rise in the frequency and intensity of disasters such as flooding, mudslides, and landslides over the past decade. Today, we examine the human toll of these floods in Kasese and explore ongoing interventions aimed at helping communities build resilience against recurring disasters.

articles.title: Mega-iceberg from Antarctica on collision course with South Georgia: Harbinger of things to come?
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: Icebergs break off of the Antarctic ice cap and drift away. Climate change is making it happen more frequently due to the warming of the climate. The icebergs are heading for the island of South Georgia, which is currently being warmed by climate change.

articles.title: 'First-of-its-kind' retirement living set to help you save on power bills
articles.summary: Professor Veronica Soebarto advises anyone looking to move to a new home to be aware of the area's climate and the direction the house faces, as these factors can influence how easy it is to heat or cool the property.    - University of Adelaide.

articles.title: Coal mine expansion plans hovering "above the law" says Lock the Gate
articles.author: Gabriel Fowler
articles.summary: Hunter coal mine is tracking to double its greenhouse gas emissions by 2026 if its expansion plans are approved without clear reduction targets, according to the company's report. The mine is located in Hunter County, New South Wales, and is located near the Hunter River.

articles.title: WNC Nature Center set to re-open in March after facing damage from Helene
articles.author: Tyler Scott
articles.summary: The WNC Nature Center is set to re-open in March after it was forced to close following the effects of Hurricane Helene. The center will be open seven days a week from 10 a.m. until 4:30 p.m., beginning March 17. The ticket office will now be cashless.

articles.title: Rising temp forces avian guests to leave Bhitarkanika early
articles.author: Ashis Senapati
articles.summary: Bhitarkanika National Park's annual bird census recorded 151,614 birds of 118 species this year. This is slightly up from last year's count of 151,421 birds of 121 species. High temperatures in the region are 3-4 degrees above normal for this time of year.

articles.title: Some people are losing family and friends over climate change denial — but they say facts matter
articles.author: Matthew Rozsa
articles.summary: Areej Shaikh lost her relationship with her climate change denialist cousin in Pakistan. Takarudana Mapendembe had a falling out with his college friend over climate change. Liam Perkins is an eco-conscious marketing manager at Privr.com.

articles.title: 568 kids from 5 panchayats of Gumla lead climate resilience initiatives
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: There are 586 children under the age of 18 from five panchayats in Gumla district taking the lead in developing resilient action plans to tackle the challenges to the environment. Gumla is a region vulnerable to climate change and is one of the most vulnerable districts in India.

articles.title: Global Food Shortage: A Scenario Becoming Reality
articles.author: Matija Šerić
articles.summary: Humanity in 2025 is facing major and pressing problems. One of the greatest emerging problems is the global food shortage, which could materialize in the coming decades. The current state of global food security is far from ideal and moving toward the worst-case scenario. In January of this year, more than 150 Nobel Prize and World Food Prize laureates warned of a potential global hunger crisis.

articles.title: J & K: Towards Climate Governance
articles.author: Sri Varshith Kumar Reddy E
articles.summary: Kashmir's water supply is under severe strain due to climate change, drought, and deforestation. The state budget of 2016-17 proposed setting up a Water Resources Department to address the water crisis in Jammu and Kashmir. The initiative precedes the Union Government's move to form the Ministry of Jal Shakti.

articles.title: WNC nature center to re-open after Helene
articles.summary: The western North Carolina Nature Center was closed for more than five months after Hurricane Helene hit.    -      i.e. the Nature Center is closed because of the hurricane Helene, which hit North Carolina in May 2011.

articles.title: Ukrainians defiant three years on from Russia invasion
articles.summary: Hundreds of people gathered at Federation Square in Melbourne on Monday to commemorate the three-year anniversary of Russia's illegal war in Ukraine. Leah Protyniak's grandparents migrated to Australia after World War II, but her remaining family in Ukraine have had their lives turned upside down. Petr Kuzmin has family in both Ukraine and Russia. His mother's cousin and family remain in the southern Ukrainian city of Kherson, which was the first city to fall in Russia's advance.

articles.title: Ukrainians defiant three years on from Russia invasion
articles.author: William Ton
articles.summary: Life in Ukraine changed when Russia invaded three years ago. Ukrainians and their Australian supporters have turned out in force to demonstrate their spirit remains unbreakable despite the invasion and the change in the political situation in Ukraine.   Â      in Ukraine

articles.title: Fluctuating Great Lakes temps prompts safety warning from Coast Guard
articles.author: Katie Sergent
articles.summary: Michiganders are urged to be careful while out on the Great Lakes due to fluctuating temperatures. Recreationalists are encouraged to stay away from cracks, seams, pressure ridges, slushy areas, darker patches of ice and ice near the shoreline of a frozen lake.

articles.title: The effect of climate change on earth's wildlife
articles.summary: In recent years we have seen a rise in natural disasters as an effect of climate change and global warming. This has a significant impact on people and the animals on our planet. Global warming has led to habitat loss for many species. The North Atlantic right whale is on the brink of extinction. Natural disasters like the LA wildfires have also had an impact on wildlife.

articles.title: Cold weather takes toll on KMAland firefighters
articles.author: Mike Peterson
articles.summary: Glenwood's Fire Department answered 34 service calls for the week ending February 18th. Fire Chief Matt Gray says the cold takes a toll on equipment and on firefighters. Firefighters take precautions to deal with the cold. Residents can help ease the burden by taking fire prevention steps.

articles.title: Granite Geek: Our winters are getting wimpier but mid-winter is still mid-winter
articles.summary: There's more snow in David Brooks' yard than he's had for at least three winters. The date at which the snowpack reaches its annual maximum has not changed, according to a study published in PLOS Climate. Basic science is the bedrock on which modern society is built.

articles.title: UN warns that ‘time is not on our side' as key climate science meeting begins
articles.author: Rosie Frost
articles.summary: The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) is meeting in Hangzhou, China to negotiate the content and timing of the next landmark assessment. It comes after several climate agencies confirmed that 2024 was the hottest year on record. The landmark reports from the IPCC were set up in 1988 to inform policymakers of the latest climate science. Some countries are pushing for the next report to be released earlier than planned. US officials from the State Department and scientists from federal agencies have been pulled out of IPCC talks by the Trump administration.

articles.title: Two continents are on a collision course which would reshape the planet
articles.author: Sinead Butler
articles.summary: Australia broke away from Antarctica 80 million years ago and it's been moving northwards ever since. The direction the continent is moving in is north, so it will collide with Asia in hundreds of millions of years. It was discovered in 2016 that Australia's GPS system was off by 1.5 meters (4.9 feet) due to the movement.

articles.title: Two continents are on a collision course which would reshape the planet
articles.author: Sinead Butler
articles.summary: Australia broke away from Antarctica 80 million years ago and it's been moving northwards ever since. The continent is drifting at around 2.8 inches (7cm) per year. It will collide with Asia in hundreds of millions of years. It's already having an impact as Australia's GPS system was off by 1.5 meters (4.9 feet) in 2016.

articles.title: Temperatures rising but is the urgency?
articles.summary: Donald Trump's decision to withdraw from the Paris Climate Agreement is bad for the planet. John Drummond writes that there is no time to waste as the climate warms and it's important to take action to deal with increased temperatures. He writes that the 1.5°C target has already been breached and we will add another 0.4°C in the next five years.

articles.title: Spring forward: Northern states to gain over 100 minutes of daylight in March
articles.author: Brian Lada
articles.summary: March marks the changing of the seasons, with meteorological spring kicking off on the first of the month. Days will become noticeably longer throughout March, with many areas of the country gaining 2 or 3 minutes of sunlight with each passing day. The biggest sunlight shift will take place on Sunday, March 9, as daylight saving time begins.

articles.title: A Peek Beneath The 'Doomsday Glacier' Has Scientists Running For Cover
articles.author: Trisha Leigh
articles.summary: The Thwaites Glacier has been retreating for 80 years and accelerating over the past 30 years. Scientists have been monitoring the glacier since 2018. The glacier is 75 miles across and contains an area of 74,000 square miles. It contributes to 4% of the current sea level rise. It is expected to collapse in the next 200 years.

articles.title: The Caspian Sea is sinking: Nearly 31,000 sq km lost since 2005
articles.author: TIMESOFINDIA.COM
articles.summary: The Caspian Sea's water levels are declining rapidly due to climate change. The sea is spread across 370,000 sq km and fed by 130 rivers. It is bordered by five countries: Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan, Russia, Turkmenistan, and Iran. Its water area has shrunk by 7.1% over the past 15 years. Experts warn that the falling water levels will have adverse effects on fishing, agriculture and tourism.

articles.title: Cataloging the changing tone of climate change coverage
articles.author: Joan Skilbred
articles.summary: The first use of the three words: warming, climate and permafrost appeared together in a News-Miner article on April 8, 1977. The next warning in the Fairbanks newspapers of what would happen if the world's climate experienced a long-term warming trend was given by Niel Davis in the Nov. 13, 1980 edition of the Pioneer All Alaska Weekly.

articles.title: Rising temp forces avian guests to leave Bhitarkanika early
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Migratory birds at Bhitarkanika National Park have begun their return journey earlier than usual this year, with mass departures observed this month instead of the usual month of January. Experts attribute the change to climate change, which is affecting the migration patterns.

articles.title: In Madagascar, the African Development Bank and the World Food Programme help people fight back against cyclones
articles.author: Maravi Post Reporter
articles.summary: Cyclone Freddy hit Madagascar in 2023. It followed Cyclone Batsirai, which had struck just a year earlier, plunging nearly 150,000 people into poverty. A chronic drought has gripped the island's south since 2009. The African Development Bank invested $20.75 million in the African Disaster Risk Financing (ADRiFi) programme to enhance climate disaster risk management and response. In five years, $15 million has already been paid to Madagascar. This compensation has enabled operators to take concrete, sustainable action, such as rebuilding traditional huts.

articles.title: Inside Australia's 'quiet collapse' that could be impossible to fix
articles.author: STEPHEN JOHNSON
articles.summary: Darin Soat is a former investment banker and the founder of the Works Media Group. He says Australia's economy is in trouble because of growing wealth inequality and a narrow focus on mineral exports. Mr Soat says Australia ranks poorly in complexity and is one of the world's least developed nations.

articles.title: Arunachal Pradesh's glaciers are shrinking rapidly, study finds
articles.summary: The study revealed that smaller glaciers are retreating faster than their larger counterparts. Dr. Jamir warned about the consequences of this rapid glacial melt. She added that over time, as the glacial mass reduces due to continuous melting, freshwater availability will decline significantly affecting agriculture, drinking water supplies, and hydropower generation in the region.

articles.title: Early summer prompts winter migrant birds to embark on homeward journey
articles.author: Statesman News Service
articles.summary: Onset of early summer in Odisha has prompted the winter migratory birds to depart early from Bhitarakanika national park after staying about two months in the winter period. The birds flew into the water bodies from places as far off as Siberia, Afghanistan, Iran, Iraq and Himalayan region.

articles.title: Ecostani: Link between rise in wildfires and atmospheric convection
articles.author: Chetan Chauhan
articles.summary: There has been an increase in the number of forest fires in India since 2010, especially in Himalayan and Deccan regions, which has witnessed deforestation of quality forests. The study found that enhanced atmospheric convection is identified for over 40% of the fires in low-human-impact regions and 61% in other places, where local ignition is also available. It also found that mid-to-high latitudes see most frequent and intensive burning in local summer and autumn whereas the subtropics show high wildfire activity in local winter and spring.

articles.title: California Map Shows Where Land Is Sinking Fastest
articles.author: Joe Edwards
articles.summary: NASA-led team has detailed the areas of California where land is sinking or rising the most. The study examined California's vertical land motion over the period from 2015 to 2023 using radar data from ESA's Sentinel-1 satellites and ground-based GPS measurements. Both manmade and natural causes were factors in ground level changes.

articles.title: Op-Ed: FEMA climate related training sidelined, local impacts
articles.author: Ted Buehner
articles.summary: Kristi Noem issued a directive to all DHS agencies to stop all work connected to climate change and the elimination of climate-related terms across the department. The 2010s was the warmest decade globally and each year so far this decade has set new high-temperature records. January 2025 will be warmest globally in the entire 176-year record. The number of disasters with a billion-dollar price tag has risen since the 1990's and FEMA has been responding to more and more disasters.

articles.title: UN climate science report talks stall as nations clash over timeline
articles.summary: Representatives of nearly 200 countries are meeting in Hangzhou to discuss the timing and content of the UN's next blockbuster assessment of global warming science. The meeting comes on the heels of the hottest year on record and rising alarm over the pace of warming. Donald Trump's withdrawal of the United States from the Paris Agreement will also cast a shadow.

articles.title: AG Chat 2/24
articles.summary: Warming trend to ramp up as February comes to a close. Learn How to Play the Ukulele with Nicole Cook. Pilot 13 First Alert Weather @10pm (12/23). Mild and more active this last week of February. Updated: February 22, 2025 at 10:59 PM CST.

articles.title: How Climate Change Is Turning Ocean Animals Into Ruthless Killers
articles.author: Belinda Jelly
articles.summary: As ocean temperatures rise, sharks are migrating to new areas. This can lead to more frequent shark attacks in areas that used to be considered safe. Warmer water temperatures can also increase their metabolism, leading them to hunt more frequently. As they venture into new territories, they pose a threat to humans and local marine ecosystems.

articles.title: Forest fires push up greenhouse gas emissions from war in Ukraine
articles.author: AOL
articles.summary: The burning of Ukraine's forests over the past year has pushed the total greenhouse emissions from the war since Russia's full-scale invasion to almost 230m tonnes, according to the study published on the website of the International Institute for Research on Climate Change (IRCC).

articles.title: A supercomputer was asked how long humanity will survive on Earth — and it confirms scientists' worst fears
articles.summary: In 250 million years, Earth will form a new supercontinent and the Sun will be brighter, according to a new study by the University of Bristol. Scientists have long raised alarm about the climate crisis and this study confirms their worst fears. The report published in Bioscience noted that the Earth was on track to experience a 2.7-degree peak warming by 2100.

articles.title: Forest fires push up greenhouse gas emissions from war in Ukraine
articles.author: Damien Gayle
articles.summary: The war in Ukraine has led to 55m tonnes of CO2-equivalent emissions in the past 12 months. In the third year of the conflict, there have been 20-25 times more forest fires than in the previous 10 years. The warfare itself has contributed the most to the climate impact, followed by reconstruction.

articles.title: Hailstorm Damages Over 20 Hectares of Crops in Kasama District - ZNBC-Just for you
articles.author: Joshua Jere
articles.summary: A hailstorm damaged maize, cassava, groundnuts and bean crops in Kasama District. 17 households have been affected in Kawama Masuwa village. The district senior agricultural officer encouraged farmers to replant beans and cassava as the planting window is still open.

articles.title: The Oceans Are Getting Hotter But They're Evaporating Less
articles.author: Stephen Luntz
articles.summary: Two-thirds of the world's oceans have experienced a slight decline in evaporation rates between 2008 and 2017. This contradicts what we would expect in a warming climate. The trend is not universal, according to the researchers, but it could have negative consequences for some places.

articles.title: CM: Sabah ready to work with stakeholders in combating climate change
articles.author: Mariah Doksil
articles.summary: Sabah State Government will collaborate with all stakeholders to combat climate change and its challenges. Chief Minister Datuk Seri Panglima Haji Hajiji Haji Noor made the remarks at the Kinabalu Convention 2025: Food Security, Climate Change and Investment on Monday. UN estimates that nearly 733 million people face hunger every day.

articles.title: Andrew Bridgen: Dr Patrick Moore, the co founder of Greenpeace is spot on regarding CO2 and the man-made climate change hoax. (Video)
articles.author: Infinite
articles.summary: Dr Patrick Moore is spot on regarding CO2 and the man-made climate change hoax, according to Andrew Bridgen.      ...  .  ..   in the tweet from Andrew Bridgens. It is February 24, 2025.

articles.title: Warm weekend weather broke temperature records in Salmon Arm, other B.C. communities
articles.author: Luc Rempel
articles.summary: Sunday's high of 12.4 C was the highest temperature recorded on that day in Salmon Arm since record keeping began in 1893. Blue River saw a high of 10.8 C. Cache Creek hit 14.7 C, beating a previous record set in 1963 by nearly two degrees. Clearwater reached 12 C to hit a new temperature record.

articles.title: EXPOSING THE GLOBALIST GENOCIDE AGENDA - THE LIGHT IS GETTING BRIGHTER AND BRIGHTER - THEIR HIDING PLACES, LIES AND DARKNESS WILL BE DESTROYED - TAKING THEM DOWN TO HELL - INFO@SAVEUSNOW.ORG.UK
articles.author: Save Us Now
articles.summary: The Globalist Generation's agenda is to destroy the hiding places, lies and darkness and to take them down to hell. The light is getting lighter and lighter and the darkness is getting darker.    Information sent to saveusnow.org.uk.

articles.title: NiMet, CARE Nigeria partner to improve climate-smart agriculture, disaster mitigation
articles.author: Favour Okpale
articles.summary: Nigerian Meteorological Agency (NiMet) and CARE Nigeria, a subsidiary of CARE USA, have agreed to collaborate on improving climate-smart agriculture and enhancing disaster mitigation efforts across Nigeria. The collaboration is expected to enhance early warning systems, improve agricultural productivity, and support communities in adapting to climate change.

articles.title: UN warns nations at climate science meeting 'time is not on our side'
articles.author: Kelly MACNAMARA
articles.summary: Tense negotiations on the timing and content of the UN's next blockbuster assessment of global warming science opened in China on Monday. US scientists are absent. The meeting in Hangzhou comes on the heels of the hottest year on record and rising alarm over the pace of warming.

articles.title: UN warns nations at climate science meeting 'time is not on our side'
articles.author: Kelly MACNAMARA
articles.summary: Tense negotiations on the timing and content of the UN's next blockbuster assessment of global warming science opened in China on Monday. US scientists are absent. The meeting comes on the heels of the hottest year on record and rising alarm over the pace of warming. Some leading emitters argue against trying to meet the deadline.

articles.title: What bird signifies spring for you? Let us know in this survey
articles.summary: The American robin, red-winged blackbird and sandhill crane are signs of spring for Paul A. Smith of the Journal Sentinel outdoors editor. Migratory birds that spend the winter in Wisconsin can still be a sign of spring, according to Paul.

articles.title: Poll suggests things are only going to get ‘worse' for Labor
articles.summary: IPA Deputy Executive Director Daniel Wild claims things are only going to get worse for Labor. The Coalition is ahead in the latest Freshwater Strategy poll. Anthony Albanese has not been a strong campaigner for Labor in the recent past.   iipa.com.

articles.title: Scientists sound alarm over record-smashing global findings — here's what's happening
articles.author: Chloe Bryant
articles.summary: This past January, global temperatures reached 55.9 degrees Fahrenheit, a 1.7 degree increase from normal for the same time of year. There was a 3.15 degree increase in air temperature compared to preindustrial levels. According to Samantha Burgess, the director of the E.U.'s Copernicus Climate Change Service, a warming global climate can be attributed to certain human activities.

articles.title: Weather alert: Cold snap expected in Kyrgyzstan
articles.author: Baktygul OSMONALIEVA
articles.summary: A cold snap is expected in Kyrgyzstan. The Hydrometeorological Service of the Ministry of Emergency Situations issued a storm warning. The weather is expected to change from February 26 to February 28. Forecasters predict occasional rain and snow, snow in the foothills and mountainous areas, and heavy precipitations in some places. The west wind will increase to 15-20 meters per second.

articles.title: Assam: Intense Rainfall And Hailstorm Disrupts Life In West Karbi Anglong
articles.author: Sentinel Digital Desk
articles.summary: West Karbi Anglong is facing intense weather conditions due to heavy rain and hailstorms. The remote village of Langhemphi, 32 km from Hamren, the district headquarters, has been hit hardest, along with Baithalangso and Zerikingding. The weather is expected to continue for several days.

articles.title: GREECE'S RECORD SNOWFALL; CYPRUS SHIVERS; RECORD COLD WEEK ACROSS THE US; + WATER VAPOR FAILURE: CLIMATE MODELS GOT IT WRONG
articles.author: Infinite
articles.summary: There was a record snowfall in Greece and a record cold week across the US. Climatologists' models are off-target on basic physical processes, as Electroverse points out.      .   in the tweet from Electroverse.

articles.title: Earth is warming faster. Scientists are closing in on why
articles.author: list.metadata.agency
articles.summary: 2023 was 0.2°C (0.4°F) hotter than expected due to climate change. The second half of 2023 saw an El Niño get under way. In 2020 new rules imposed by the IMO had slashed the amount of sulphur allowed in the fuel of ships on the high seas.

articles.title: A closer look at one of Lee County's most important and frustrating FDOT projects
articles.author: Mark H. Bickel
articles.summary: Southwest Florida is still recovering from recent hurricanes. The Little Pine Island Bridge, which connects Pine Island with Matlacha was damaged by Helene and Milton last year. The Florida Department of Transportation is in charge of the project in the first of three phases, which started toward the end of 2024.

articles.title: How to turn Africa's progressive legal frameworks into real benefits for climate refugees
articles.author: Africa migration
articles.summary: The number of people displaced by extreme weather events in Africa rose 600% between 2009 and 2023. Africa has some of the most progressive legal frameworks for protecting refugees, but implementation is compromised by various factors, including rising nationalism and waning political will to support refugees. By 2050, up to 5% of Africa's population could be on the move due to climate change.

articles.title: https://www.facebook.com/Flash.Burn.Australia/
articles.summary: Flash Burn Australia is a corneal injury that results from exposure to UV radiation. It is similar to sunburn, but it affects the eyes rather than the skin. The product is on sale now for a limited time only at SupplementCarts.com.

articles.title: World's most rapidly moving continent Australia is heading to collide with Asia - what does this mean for the future
articles.author: TOI Science Desk
articles.summary: Australia's northward drift towards Asia is a geological process that will reshape not only the continent but also the natural and technological face of the world. It is already having real-world effects on modern technology and infrastructure. In 2016, scientists discovered that Australia's shift had moved its entire GPS coordinate system 1.5 meters (4.9 feet) off its original position.

articles.title: Weather tracker: temperatures hit record highs across South America
articles.author: The Observer
articles.summary: Record high temperatures were recorded across South America last week. North America was hit by cold and wintry conditions. South America is in its final month of summer. Rio de Janeiro recorded record high temperatures last week, compared to last week's cold snap in North America.

articles.title: Australians should be ‘very worried' about China's live fire drills
articles.summary: Strategic Analysis Australia's Michael Shoebridge claims Australians should be'very worried' about the Chinese warships conducting live fire testing off the coast of Australia. He claims it's dangerous in and of itself but it's a sign of China growing their military presence in our peaceful South Pacific neighbourhood.

articles.title: Climate change worsening psychological trauma, expert warns
articles.author: Punch
articles.summary: Dr Chima Okoro is a lecturer from the Department of Psychology at the University of Lagos. He believes climate change contributes to the rise of psychological trauma in the country. He spoke on the topic to the news agency.   Click here to read the full article.

articles.title: Greenpeace co-founder, Dr. Patrick Moore: 'The future will show that this whole hysteria over climate change was a complete fabrication.' (Video)
articles.author: Infinite
articles.summary: Greenpeace co-founder, Dr. Patrick Moore, believes that the future will show that the hysteria over climate change was a complete fabrication and that it's all a hoax.    pic.twitter.com/ZZyZG8j7AQ

articles.title: Climate change: Glacier melt accelerating globally, warn scientists
articles.summary: The world's glaciers are rapidly melting as the world warms. There was a sharp increase in melting over the past decade, with around 36 percent more ice lost in the 2012 to 2023 period than in the years from 2000 to 2011. The glaciers are the second-largest contributor to global sea-level rise.

articles.title: Household solar panels create a 'worry' for energy boss
articles.author: Jennifer Dudley-Nicholson
articles.summary: Australia is leading the solar race worldwide thanks to widespread adoption of rooftop panels. But the asset could present a serious challenge to the national grid in the short-term, according to leading energy regulator, the Australian Renewable Energy Regulator (ARER).

articles.title: Cassowary: Meet most feared dagger-clawed creature of Australia
articles.author: Web Desk
articles.summary: Aussies are afraid of the cassowary, which is one of the national symbols of Australia. Cassowaries live in the tropical forests of Papua New Guinea, the Moluccas and northeastern Australia. They are flightless and have large dagger-like claws and piercing eyes.

articles.title: Fire Survivors Demand Action in New Declaration
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: It's been five years since the devastating Black Summer bushfires. On Wednesday 26 February, survivors will gather in Sydney to launch and sign onto a new Australian Bushfire Survivor Declaration. BSCA has invited politicians from fire-impacted regions to meet with bushfire survivors and hear their calls for urgent climate action.

articles.title: Three years of war in Ukraine: ‘Environmental damage knows no borders' as emissions rise to new high
articles.author: Rosie Frost
articles.summary: Russia's invasion of Ukraine has emitted nearly 230 million tonnes of CO2 equivalents since it began on 24 February 2022. The total is now the same as the annual emissions of Austria, Hungary, Czech Republic and Slovakia combined. Ukraine is seeking damages for the carbon emissions of war.

articles.title: Global Heating in The Coldest Place on Earth
articles.summary: Antarctica is the coldest, driest and windiest place in the world. It is experiencing dramatic consequences from global heating. Antarctica is home to a range of extraordinary wildlife that live here in these challenging conditions. The continent is also the world's largest natural laboratory for research on climate change, geology, ecology and biodiversity.

articles.title: Coalition to target 'politicised' Climate Change Authority led by former Liberal MP
articles.summary: Mr Kean says Australia is at a fork in the road and has to choose between adhering to its Paris agreement targets of 1.5 degrees warming and a rise of 2.6 degrees, which would be catastrophic for Australia's economy and the environment.

articles.title: Weather warming after record cold
articles.summary: It was the second coldest February in Swift Current area recorded with data that goes back 140 years. The temperatures started to rise late last week and should stick around until the end of February. The ground is still cold so we should be careful when dealing with likely icy conditions.

articles.title: Glaciers melting faster than ever, deepening global climate crisis
articles.author: Associated Press
articles.summary: The world's mountain glaciers are shrinking more than twice as fast as they were in the early 2000s. The world's glaciers have lost more than 7 trillion tons of ice (6.5 trillion metric tons) since 2000. Alaska's glaciers are melting at the fastest rate of any of the 19 regions studied, losing 67 billion tons a year. Central Europe's glaciers lost the highest percentage of ice in the past 24 years.

articles.title: Nearly 200 countries to discuss UN climate science report at Hangzhou meeting
articles.author: Kelly Macnamara
articles.summary: Representatives of nearly 200 countries gather Monday in Hangzhou to continue negotiations on the timing and content of the UN's next blockbuster assessment of global warming science. The meeting comes on the heels of the hottest year on record and rising alarm over the pace of warming. Donald Trump's withdrawal of the United States from the Paris Agreement will also cast a shadow.

articles.title: Meet Cassowary, World's Most Dangerous Bird Capable Of Killing A Human
articles.author: NDTV News Desk
articles.summary: Cassowaries live in the tropical rainforests of Australia and New Guinea. The bird is beautiful and dangerous due to its vivid blue face, helmet-like headdress, and razor-sharp claws. They are not violent and rarely attack humans, but if offended or enraged, they may cause a great deal of harm.

articles.title: 'India, Pakistan at risk': Australia's collision with Asia will form new mountain ranges and alter coastlines
articles.author: Wion Web Desk
articles.summary: The Australian continent is moving north at a rate of 7 cm per year. This gradual shift is caused by plate tectonics. It is expected to lead to a collision with Asia in the distant future, as scientists have said.

articles.title: Rethinking Climate Risks: Why Richer, Colder Nations Face Bigger Economic Losses
articles.author: Co E-EDP
articles.summary: The IMF working paper "A New Perspective on Temperature Shocks" by Nooman Rebei challenges long-standing assumptions about the economic effects of climate change. It shows that long-term climate change is hitting advanced economies harder than previously thought. Colder regions are seeing the sharpest absolute temperature increases. Under extreme climate scenarios, advanced economies could suffer output losses as high as 6% by the end of the century.

articles.title: Launching the Art For Climate Festival Halong 2025
articles.author: Thai An
articles.summary: Art For Climate Festival is taking place from February 20 to June 10 in Halong Bay. The festival aims to honour the natural heritage and promote the values of national and international cultural heritages. According to the United Nations, the climate will be four times harsher by the year 2100 even if the earth's surface temperature increases by 1.5 degrees Celsius.

articles.title: ABC 10News Pinpoint Weather with Max Goldwasser: Record-setting temps on the way
articles.author: KGTV
articles.summary: Record-setting temps are on the way, according to Max Goldwasser at ABC 10 News Pinpoint Weather with Max Gold wsser.      Â  .   in the forecast.  in this case, the temperature will reach 40 degrees.

articles.title: FFA chapter giving much-needed boost for western NC farmers reeling from Helene
articles.author: WRAL
articles.summary: Helene devastated crops, equipment and land in western North Carolina. State and federal aid has been slow to arrive. A chapter chapter is giving much-needed boost to farmers reeling from Helene's devastation. It's been months since Hurricane Helene hit the area.

articles.title: Agriculture: Promoting climate resilient agriculture
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Agriculture is a climate sensitive sector. Livestock and rice generate greenhouse gas emissions, but also contribute to climate change, according to the UNFCCC. It is also a source of CO2 emissions in the agriculture sector, but it is not the only one.

articles.title: Agriculture: Promoting climate resilient agriculture
articles.author: Nasir Ali Panhwar
articles.summary: Agriculture is a climate sensitive sector. Livestock and rice generate significant greenhouse gas emissions. Traditional farming often uses resource intensive processes such as land clearance, excessive water use, and agrochemical application. Extreme weather events such as droughts, floods, and heatwaves become more frequent and severe. Smallholder farmers need support. Nature based climate solutions offer significant social, environmental, cultural and economic benefits.

articles.title: Glaciers Worldwide are Melting Faster Causing Sea Levels to Rise More
articles.author: Universe Today
articles.summary: Anthropogenic climate change is creating a vicious circle where rising temperatures are causing glaciers to melt at an increasing rate. It also contributes to rising sea levels, coastal flooding, and extreme weather. Community estimate of global glacier mass changes from 2000 to 2023 is as follows:

articles.title: Nations at odds over major UN climate science report
articles.summary: Representatives of nearly 200 countries gather in Hangzhou on Monday to continue negotiations on the timing and content of the UN's next blockbuster assessment of global warming science. The meeting comes on the heels of the hottest year on record and rising alarm over the pace of warming. Donald Trump's withdrawal of the United States from the Paris Agreement will also cast a shadow.

articles.title: Why the U.S. has been home to Earth's most unusually cold air this year
articles.author: Ben Noll
articles.summary: The polar vortex has taken on an unexpected pattern this winter. The vortex has been located hundreds of miles south of the North Pole. It's made the United States the most unusually cold place on the planet so far this year, at least so far so far.

articles.title: Coastal areas witness mangrove deforestation
articles.author: Syed Ashraf Ali
articles.summary: Mangroves are protected under national and international laws and cannot be cut down. Since 1980, the federal and provincial institutions have allowed the occupation of two to three kilometres of the coastal land for the construction of expensive residential and commercial schemes. According to a report published by the World Wildlife Fund, 200 hectares of mangroves have been lost between 2010 and 2022 due to illegal activities of mafias and land acquisition for residential, commercial and industrial purposes.

articles.title: Fake Nuclear Fight Masks Real Climate Issues
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Climate Change Authority has rejected the Coalition's nuclear proposal. Rod Campbell, Research Director at The Australia Institute, thinks it's a distraction from the real climate issues. He thinks the CCA should focus on Australia's subsidised fossil fuel expansion and rising domestic emissions.

articles.title: How Antarctica's melting ice sheet could change NZ's climate
articles.author: Newstalk ZB
articles.summary: First-of-its-kind study suggests the ongoing melting of Antarctica's vast ice sheet could have direct implications for sea and air temperatures around New Zealand in the future. The ice sheet has been losing mass over the last few decades and will lose more as the planet warms.

articles.title: Chinese Live-Fire Drills in Tasman Sea Disrupt Commercial Air Traffic
articles.summary: The Chinese PLA Navy carried out live-fire drills in the Tasman Sea last Tuesday, forcing the diversion of several passenger jets. The Chinese foreign ministry claims that there was no impact on air traffic safety. It is customary for safety purposes for civil aviation to give at least 12-24 hours of advance notice to civil aviation.

articles.title: Small ash emissions observed at Whakaari
articles.author: Newstalk ZB
articles.summary: Small ash emissions and large steam plumes have been observed at Whakaari/White Island recently. Volcanic Alert Level remains at 2 and Aviation Colour Code has changed to Orange. Steam, gas and ash emissions remain variable as they have been for the past few months.

articles.title: Sea-Level Rise: A New Method To Estimate The Probability Of Different Outcomes Including A Worst Case
articles.author: MENA FN
articles.summary: Sea-level rise will continue to threaten ecosystems, communities and cities in the coming decades, no matter how quickly we reduce our CO2 emissions, according to Mefern's article in "The Conversation".   .     Â

articles.title: The Oceans Are Getting Hotter But They're Evaporating Less
articles.author: IFL Science
articles.summary: Sea surface temperatures have been rising for at least 45 years. For most of that time, evaporation increased with them, bringing more rain. Since 2008, however, there has been a decline in ocean surface temperature. This decline may reflect natural climate oscillations, according to scientists.

articles.title: Australians record highest breast cancer diagnosis rate in the world
articles.author: system
articles.summary: the country's high breast cancer rate. An aging population, alcohol consumption and low physical activity could all be contributing to the problem, according to Australian scientists.   .   and they say it could be due to an aging population and alcohol consumption, or because of poor physical activity.

articles.title: Poll: Americans remain deeply divided over climate change
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: A significant portion of Americans remains skeptical about climate change, according to the latest I&I/TIPP Poll data. Some 1,478 adults participated in an online poll asking how much they trust statements made by climate change activists and policymakers. The US has purported to join international agreements and initiatives that do not reflect the country's values.

articles.title: Greeks Speak Out: Poll Unveils Key Public Concerns
articles.author: Greek Reporter
articles.summary: Economic instability, demographic decline and climate change are among the top concerns worrying Greeks. Only 27.4 percent view Greek democracy as'strong'. 76 percent believe coastal countries such as Greece will be more heavily affected by climate change. 9 out of 10 respondents believe climate change impacts the seas and oceans.

articles.title: Climate, mental health resilience program brought to Cotabato City
articles.author: Sun Star
articles.summary: Extreme weather events such as typhoons, floods and droughts threaten 60% of our land and 74% of the Philippine population. These climate-induced disasters hit rural and farming communities the hardest. This collaboration underscores the importance of multi-sectoral efforts in addressing the dual challenges of climate change and public health.

articles.title: Sea-level rise: A new method to estimate the probability of different outcomes—including a worst case
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Sea-level rise will continue to threaten ecosystems, communities and cities, no matter how quickly we reduce our carbon emissions, given the long-drawn-out impact of climate warming on the oceans and ice sheets. High-end sea-level rises should be planned for.

articles.title: A multi-billion-dollar rule targeting homeowners and renters makes no sense
articles.author: Orange County Register
articles.summary: At the turn of the century, policy 'elites' spoke of climate change, not global warming. Now they talk about global warming'solutions' that mandate increased electrification. Today, the air we breathe is dramatically worse than before, because of the increase in electric vehicles.

articles.title: China denies Australia's complaint over live-fire naval drills
articles.author: MENA FN
articles.summary: China denies Australia's protest as "hyped up" and "inconsistent with the facts" on its latest live-fire marine training in international seas between Australia and New Zealand. China is concerned about the training taking place between the two countries' international seas.

articles.title: Ruta Mave: Cook Islands, it's time to wake up
articles.author: Cook Islands News
articles.summary: The proposed passport and the China deal shaking up the Cook Islands relationship with New Zealand are upsetting the men. Cook Islands are going to build ports with China, while their warships are firing live rounds off Australia's coast.    It's only February. Men are upset.

articles.title: Nuclear path would blow out Australia's emissions targets, new modelling shows
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Coalition's nuclear plan would add 200 years of domestic air travel for Australia, according to new analysis from the Climate Change Authority. It's estimated that additional emissions from adopting the nuclear plan equate to 200 years' worth of air travel per person per year.

articles.title: PAGASA: Shear line weakens but rains to persist due to easterlies
articles.author: Manila Bulletin
articles.summary: The effect of the shear line has weakened, but rains may still affect some areas, according to PAGASA. The shear is formed by the collision of cold winds from the northeast monsoon (amihan) and warm breezes from the Pacific Ocean.

articles.title: What it's like to live in Greenland
articles.author: Yahoo Daily News
articles.summary: Life along the west coast of Greenland, high above the Arctic Circle, is very different from that on the east coast of the country.      Â   y   in the north of Greenland is called "Arctic Circle".

articles.title: Guterres expresses deep concern over colonists' violence in West Bank
articles.author: Ammon
articles.summary: António Guterres is concerned about the growing violence in the world. He expressed his concerns to the UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterre on the issue. He also expressed his concern about the situation in Syria and Afghanistan. The situation in Afghanistan is also a concern.

articles.title: The Caspian Sea is sinking: Nearly 31,000 sq km lost since 2005
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: The Caspian Sea water levels are declining rapidly. Environmental activists are concerned and alarmed over the phenomenon. Vadim Ni, founder of the Save The Caspians Sea Ecological Society, is concerned about the situation. He believes that climate change is a real issue.

articles.title: Cataloging the changing tone of climate change coverage
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Climate change and the resulting warming trends have dominated news headlines over the past decade. The documentation and reporting on the topic of a warming climate in our local newspapers goes back further than what many of us commonly know.   Â    .

articles.title: US judge to hear AP challenge to Trump's ban over use of Gulf of Mexico name
articles.author: News India Times
articles.summary: Donald Trump issued an executive order calling on U.S. institutions to refer to the Gulf of Mexico as the "Gulf of America" in Boca del Rio, Veracruz state, Mexico February 18, 2025. The order was signed by President Barack Obama.

articles.title: Arctic study urges stronger climate action to prevent catastrophic warming
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: There was a time when 2 degrees Celsius of global warming was the doomsday scenario. Now we are staring down the barrel of a much higher temperature rise than 2 degrees C degrees Celsius. It is now more than a serious concern for the future of the planet.

articles.title: UN warns nations 'time is not on our side' on climate change
articles.author: Oman Observer
articles.summary: Tense negotiations on the timing and content of the UN's next blockbuster assessment of global warming science opened in China on Monday. US scientists are reportedly negotiating the timing of the assessment with Chinese and French scientists. US and Chinese scientists are also negotiating the content of it.

articles.title: Climate change shrinks glaciers faster than ever
articles.author: Richmond Times Dispatch
articles.summary: Climate change is accelerating the melting of the world's mountain glaciers, according to a new study. The glaciers are shrinking more than twice as fast as in the early 2000s, the study found.      Â  .   in the

articles.title: World's most rapidly moving continent Australia is heading to collide with Asia - what does this mean for the future
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Australia is shifting by 2.8 inches (7 cm) every year. This is equal to the way human fingernails grow. Australia is migrating north towards Asia at a very unexpected pace.  .    .   i

articles.title: Nations at odds over major UN climate science report
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Representatives of nearly 200 countries gather in Hangzhou on Monday to continue negotiations on the timing and content of the UN's next blockbuster assessment of global warming science. Donald Trump's withdrawal of the United States from the Paris Agreement will also cast a shadow over the talks.
